etymology.description: 宠(寵, to favor; pamper) + 物(thing; creature) = pampered creature (pet).
etymology.interpretation: Combines the idea of indulgence with 'creature,' highlighting animals kept and doted on by humans. Emphasizes companionship rather than utility.
etymology.simplification: 寵 was simplified to 宠 by replacing 龍 with 龙 and dropping the 心 component, reducing strokes for ease of writing; 物 is unchanged.

parts.english: to favor; to pamper; to dote on; favored

examples.chinese: 我家有两只可爱的宠物(我家有兩隻可愛的寵物)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ jiā yǒu liǎng zhī kě'ài de chǒngwù.
examples.english: My family has two cute pets.

examples.chinese: 他从小想养宠物(他從小想養寵物)，后来选择了一只猫(後來選擇了一隻貓)。
examples.pinyin: Tā cóng xiǎo xiǎng yǎng chǒngwù, hòulái xuǎnzé le yì zhī māo.
examples.english: Since childhood he wanted to keep a pet, and later he chose a cat.

examples.chinese: 宠物生病时(寵物生病時)，我们会带它去动物医院(我們會帶它去動物醫院)。
examples.pinyin: Chǒngwù shēngbìng shí, wǒmen huì dài tā qù dòngwù yīyuàn.
examples.english: When a pet is sick, we take it to the animal hospital.
